STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition:

International Health Regulations (IHR) - The IHR provide an overarching legal framework that defines countries’ rights and obligations in handling public health events and emergencies that have the potential to cross borders. They are an instrument of international law that is legally-binding on 196 countries, including the 194 WHO Member States.

Core capacities - The public health capacities required to detect, assess, notify and report events, and respond to public health risks and emergencies of national and international concern.
DATA_COMP: No calculations were performed in the data acquisition of this indicator as appropriate data was readily available in the final format specified by this indicator.

other_info:
Ghana is a party to the [International Health Regulations (IHR)](https://www.who.int/health-topics/international-health-regulations) designed to help protect all States from the international spread of diseases. Some achievements under the IHR include:

- Establishment of a National IHR Focal Point located at the [Disease Surveillance Department](https://ghs.gov.gh/disease-surveillance-department/) of Ghana Health Service (GHS)

- Regular monitoring of the progress of implementation of the IHR by the WHO Secretariat

- Ghana has adopted the [Second Edition IDSR Guidelines](https://www.cdc.gov/globalhealth/healthprotection/idsr/pdf/technicalguidelines/idsr-technical-guidelines-2nd-edition_2010_english.pdf), which also promotes [IHR (2005)](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/246107/9789241580496-eng.pdf) implementation

- Development of IHR Website

- Training of staff at designated Points of Entry on IHR Core capacity requirements 

Kindly refer to the [Overview of International Health Regulations 2005 (Ghana 2017)](https://www.afro.who.int/sites/default/files/2017-10/TEACHING%20PANEL%20final.pdf) for more information.
